prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Spatial resolution: Our sample is at a distance of 1-4.5 kpc, and we aim to resolve individual envelopes at sizes of ~1000-3000 AU. This can be achieved with 0.6" angular resolution corresponding to 600-3000 AU spatial resolution.
Spectral setup: We aim to cover the 7.5 GHz bandwidth available (Fig.3) at a spectral resolution of 1.12 MHz. Baseband4 (333.5-335.3 GHz) is the most line-free band for the continuum. Baseband3 (335.3-337.2 GHz) covers the C17O (3-2) line and several CH3OH transitions. Baseband2 (345.3-347.1 GHz) covers the CO (3-2) line, as well as H13CN(4-3), HC3N (38-37), SO (8-7), H13CO+(4-3). Baseband1 (347.1-349.05) covers the SiO (8-7), HN13C (4-3), H2CS (10-9) lines. In Fig.3 a comparison with the typical hot core (G34) illustrates that the requested frequency range covers several transitions mainly targeting the warm, more excited gas component.
Sensitivity: The continuum is correlated at 345 GHz in a 7.5 GHz bandwidth, together with key molecular tracers to distinguish between pre-/protostellar fragments. We therefore first argue for the line sensitivity and justify that it fulfills our continuum requests (see below).
Line: Our APEX CO (3-2) mapping indicates emission in the line wings (up to 20-30 km/s off from the vlsr, Fig.2) at an average 3.6 Jy/beam (~0.1 K in the 19.2" beam). Assuming an elongated morphology extending in a ~10"x2" area (estimated from similar objects in Duarte-Cabral et al. 2013) and a uniform distribution in a 0.6" beam we expect to see (emission area/beam area) ~50 mJy emission. For a 5 S/N detection therefore 10mJy 1sigma noise level is requested at the finest (1.12 MHz, 1.2 km/s) spectral resolution. We note, that the S/N can be increased by smoothing up to 2-3 km/s for the CO (3-2) line. This sensitivity is reached in ~3min integration time per source according to the OT. In addition, Our APEX/FLASH mapping indicates compact emission for the SiO (8-7) and SO lines (with wings and an intensity above 0.5~K Tmb), therefore we will very likely detect the peak emission of these lines as well. We correlate the 7.5~GHz bandwidth available to look for tracers of hot-core like emission, which should be boosted in the small beam.
Continuum: We target the brightest sources from ATLASGAL, so our sample has a peak flux >5 Jy/19.2"beam of APEX at 345 GHz. We account for a pessimistic 98% flux loss for a protocluster with substantial fragmentation and a dominating amount of extended dust emission, which reduces the expected peak flux to 0.1 Jy/0.6" beam. Accounting for a dynamic range of ~100, we will be sensitive to 1 mJy fragments corresponding to sub solar mass envelopes at 4.5 kpc. A 0.2 mJy 1sigma continuum sensitivity is the pessimistic lower limit on the requested sensitivity, since likely the achievable dynamic range is going to dictate the final noise level. This sensitivity is reached in the above requested integration time considering up to 60% line contamination in the band.
ACA: Emission is expected for the continuum and for the lines (mainly for CO, C17O) from larger than 20" scales (APEX/SABOCA/FLASH observations). The 7m array observations are therefore needed for both the continuum as well as the lines. We do have zero-spacings (TP) observations already in hand with APEX for 50% of the sample, the rest will be completed in the MPI APEX time. These maps will be made public, nevertheless we leave it for the observatory to decide whether TP observations will be carried out for this project.
Imaging: According to our simulations (Fig.4.) the requested ~3min/source integration time will be sufficient for a high fidelity imaging. The dust peak positions are known to an accuracy of 2-3" from ATLASGAL, therefore mosaicing is not necessary.
Special constrains: high overheads for a sample of bright sources is not avoidable. Our sample is complete to the justified mass limit.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The origin of massive stars is a fundamental open issue in modern astrophysics. Pre-ALMA interferometric studies reveal precursors to early B to late O type stars with collapsing envelopes of 15-20 Msol in 1000-3000 AU. There are exceptionally few examples known to date of more massive envelopes at these size-scales. Do massive collapsing envelopes exist within this size-scale up to the 100msol regime? Do they form the same way as the so far observed 8-20 Msol regime? To answer these questions a statistical sample is the necessary next step. Here we target a well characterized sample of massive and cold clumps above 650 Msol within 4.5 kpc identified by the ATLASGAL survey in order to reveal the most massive individual collapsing envelopes on 3000 AU size scales (with 0.6" angular resolution). We will drastically increase the number of 20-100 Msol envelopes known to date. We also target molecular tracers to distinguish between pre-stellar and protostellar condensations allowing statistical life-time estimates for the elusive pre-stellar phase. This comprehensive study represents a significant leap forward in our understanding of the origin of the most massive stars.
